Ajax is performed on the client side, meaning in your browser. Your browser has no real connection to your server, it only performs requests and displays responses via HTTP.
It's smart enough to know that an ajax call to '/api/posts' should map to the domain you're currently browsing, but that results in the same lookup as if it were hardcoded with the full domain.
This is just the nature of ajax, it's an asynchronous request to a URL over HTTP.
It's worth noting that your browser / ISP / DNS performing a lookup of a domain and routing to the correct place happens in a fraction of a second.

An ajax request is similar (bar the verb like posting data) to pasting the link into your browser and hitting enter, It resolves the domain and requests the URL just like anything else, and that's ok. In fact, it's the basis that runs the internet, it's more than ok!

You've posted a lot of threads about this bit of code..
1. Your controller is trying to echo each value that gets passed to it, which is going to do nothing. If you want to debug what the controller is receiving use dd($order_check); which will dump all the values of $order_check and halt execution.
2. You're using $_POST to send the form but your $request-get() method is trying to get things from $_GET, you need to use $request-input().

WRITING.TITLE: Looking for cheap USB stick run CDJ's or similar
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey guys,
I've moved overseas and left a lot of my gear behind. The biggest being a pair of CDJ-2000.
Nowdays it seems standard for DJs to run off USB sticks, with CDJ's like the 2000-nexus or even the cheaper CDJ-350 working really well with high quality files from your USB stick slotting right onto the deck. I've got plenty of mixing experience but need something to practice on
CDJ-350s run around 700 for a pair, which is reasonable, but I don't want to spend that on something temporary.
I'm looking for the absolute cheapest pair of decks I can use with USB sticks, the kicker being without a laptop. I've got a mixer and soundcard etc if it's needed. Basically I want to practice playing on very cheap equipment via USB sticks to get into mixing without turntables. I don't want to spend much as I'll eventually get my CDJs shipped over.
Does anyone have suggestions for cheap decks to run music off USB sticks? I'm going to have to pony up the CDJ-350s otherwise and my bank account would rather not. Are there any controllers that don't require a laptop?
Appreciate any suggestions!

It's really helped me hit the ground running with ideas that pop into my head

Face masks do not stop you getting sick. 90% of the time germs are contracted via your hands. Wash your hands as soon as you get to work / home and you'll be fine. Cold weather doesn't get you sick either. Eat well, rest well, getting sick 8 or 9 times in a season is an indicator of a bad immune system, not a foreign country..

sorry i really typed that out quickly.
In regards to JSON I was meaning the format in which your game server and database server communicate. For the kind of things you'd want in a database server json would be a pretty good option.
I would write the database server in PHP because I'm a PHP dev by day, but it's probably not the best language to write a web API for a game in. You want this to be the fastest it can be and there's probably better options than PHP.
If you run purely P2P multiplayer sessions (I don't know if you do or not) you don't need a game server at all, you could access the endpoints of your API directly from the client. In this situation the database server would take over validating the input of the methods making sure players are only doing things they should.

Ahh I get ya,
You're probably going to have a GameServer, which will handle things like player positions, chat, things like that and then what we can call a DatabaseServer which would hold things like usernames, passwords, inventories, logout locations etc
Your client would connect to the game server and the game server would connect to the database server, getting users information as they login. The game server then can verify commands from players based on their input and update the database accordingly.
The important thing here is the game server only has methods that are valid, and it verifies them before ever touching the database server.
If I were to do this, I'd write the game server in Unity, using some of those amazing libraries and setup the database server as a PHP+MYSQL box, writing the methods with JSON i/o.
Hope that makes sense.

Not if your client is the one communicating with the database. Your game client should have ZERO database info inside it. No exceptions.
Your game client shouldn't care about SQL, it should only communicate via specific methods to a game server (via JSON, XML or similar) which runs queries, calculations etc.
Your game client should have absolutely ZERO authority over the games state, user state etc.

I mainly focus around PHP MVC, specifically Laravel. By doing this I can guarantee top security, code quality and performance.
I can help with, in any capacity:
-Ecommerce websites
-Blogs portfolios
-Forums, communties etc
-Bespoke projects of any genre
-Hosting and system administration
-SEO and search rankings
-API consumption, Social media etc
My base rate is around 50 p/hour however I will always finalize a price before work begins, so no unexpected billings. This isn't a bedroom developer who's done a few tutorials, I am a professional with a huge range of projects under my belt. My usual daily rate in London is 400 but don't let that put you off contacting me as I'm desperate for some extra cash and more than happy to accommodate.
Give me a PM and we can discuss.
Let's make your project happen!

Yeah 20% is a very low tax rate, for a business or an individual. The tax benefits of a LTD company with individual tax free allowances means paying yourself from a LTD company nets you more money. It does mean you're paying tax 'twice' but the rates and allowances mean the overall amount is actually less.

Actually registering as a limited liability company gives you tax benefits compared to processing income directly as an individual. In almost every country it's better to be self employed under your own LTD than invoicing as an individual

Can definitely appreciate that and in no way would I say that I've never seen some amazing sets on NI controllers etc because I absolutely have.
I guess I'm just concerned the skill in DJing is being replaced by software. DJs in bars used to at least be able to beatmix, as they only had CDJs or Turntables. These days I'm seeing more and more controllers and laptops with the DJ hitting sync and slowing dragging the crossfader across for a traincrash mix. I know that's not everybody, and these tools and features can allow for some amazing live sets but it also lowers the barrier to entry for a lot of people who should still be in their bedroom counting beats.
Sorry for the rant! I'm definitely keeping an eye on NI's stuff. They've done a lot of good for the EDM scene over the years.

WRITING.TITLE: [META] Feedback threads littering the subreddit.
WRITING.TEXT:
I enjoy listening to peoples work in progress and try to encourage people to get feedback from other producers but whenever I'm on this subreddit I feel like they clutter and detract away from real content and discussions.
Could we have a weekly (or monthly?) feedback thread and encourage people to post there instead? /r/edmproduction do a similar thing and it works a lot better.
DnB is getting bigger and bigger recently thanks to the likes of the Sigma boys and others, this subreddit has great potential and it's a shame to see discussions ignored as they get bumped off the front page by the constant influx of soundcloud links.
I'm not sure if this is a popular opinion or not, what do you guys think? I'd definitely post more DnB content here if it was more of an active discussion board rather than a link spam board.

While it's very cool, as a DJ it doesn't excite me very much. The best sets I've seen still come out of 2 turntables / CDJs and not a laptop and a bpm synced controller

Labels websites usually list an email address or similar to send demos to. The standard in EDM seems to be a PRIVATE soundcloud link in an email.
tips:
-Only send 1 or 2 tunes. Mention you've got more but represent yourself and your style in one tune and try show diversity in another. If they want more, they'll ask.
-Keep it short and sweet, give a small outline about your career so far, any notable achievements and try to give a reason why you'd fit into the labels style.
-Use different private links for different labels, put their name in the title.
-DON'T RELEASE ANYTHING IF YOU'RE GOING TO TRY GET ON A LABEL. If you've already blown half the bang by uploading your best tune to soundcloud / spotify / beatport then labels are not going to be very interested, they're looking to craft a release around their own style, audience etc. And they're definitely better at it than me or you.
GOOD LUCK!

In that case, somewhere in your database will be a list of cities, right? And those cities have ID's from the database.
Your select would look like this, generated from the database table
select name="city"
option value="1"City Number 1/option
/select
Your controller would then look up the ID selected, grab the slug (also in the database) and redirect to the correct /about/{city} url.

By default, it's really awesome. http://blog.jetbrains.com/webide/2013/02/using-the-rest-client-within-phpstorm/

PHPstorm has third party plugins too, quite a lot! https://plugins.jetbrains.com/phpStorm
Honestly, if I had to go back to netbeans, it wouldn't be the end of the world, I'm just enjoying PHPstorm. No bad blood for netbeans and in terms of free IDEs it's my goto recommendation!

In terms of full IDE's I've got good experience with PHPstorm and Netbeans, currently settled on the former.
PHPstorm has all the things I need, a REST client, GUI for git merging, 2 key combos commit and push my code, PSR formatting to name a few.
It's true that netbeans has plugins or extensions for all of these things too, I used a lot of them. I find however that everything in PHPstorm follows the same workflow or practice, as for netbeans plugins, you're at a mercy of the plugin developer and I'd often find different plugins have completely different workflows or ideas about how to achieve something. PHPstorm just feels like a more integrated experience.
Just my 2c

These negotiations were not about pay, but the mandatory night shifts. This is not a tactic by TFL to pay employees less..

There's no talk about a race to the bottom, as you put it. It's simply a question of employees not wanting their work life to change, but as is the nature of technology, progress, whatever you want to call it, things change.
A few drivers have come out publicly to say this strike isn't about pay, but about the mandatory night shifts. If that's their sticking point then it's no wonder TFL couldn't reach an agreement, as the unions are fighting change within the LU system, a change that needs to happen to continue progress in many sectors of London.
But now I guess you're going to say there's no value in a night tube service too..

Many of us here survive on less and there's no shortage of people who would like to have a job within London Underground. The concept TFL are proposing (night shifts to start a 24 hour tube service) is not new to anyone who does shift work. If people are really concerned about doing 54 night shifts (instead of the current 7-14 night shifts) per year they are more than welcome to leave and make space for someone who has no issue with it.
Technology changes, services change, job descriptions change. If it were not for the unions this would be a pretty simple restructuring period.
I have friends here who work a similar schedule of shifts for a lot less than these people get.
after tax and contributions you're looking around 3,200
